etymologies: late 16th century. From (i) classical Latin epichīrēma (also epichērēma) syllogistic form of argument in which the premises themselves were often regarded as requiring proof

definitions: (A) A deductive argument in which some of the supporting reasons are stated briefly or incompletely. (b) A syllogism including proofs of one or both of the premises.

notes.text: The uses in English derive from various interpretations of Aristotle, and occur mainly in contexts where the meaning intended is either vague or explicitly explained.
